content: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 provides legal relief for victims of sexual abuse and harassment at educational institutions, prohibiting discrimination based on sex in programs receiving federal funding. The Supreme Court has ruled that schools can be held liable for a lack of response to such incidents, and federal agencies like the Department of Education enforce this responsibility. Title IX is enforced through private rights of action against schools and by federal agencies providing funding to educational programs. Compliance with Title IX is a condition for receiving federal funding in any education program, applying to all federally-funded schools. Title IX applies to all levels of education, with public school districts and higher education institutions receiving federal financial assistance. While the text of Title IX does not explicitly mention sexual abuse or harassment, Department of Education guidance instructs schools on addressing allegations of sexual harassment. Educational institutions have developed procedures in response to these guidelines. The Department of Education provides guidance to schools on their responsibilities under Title IX for addressing sexual harassment allegations. Recently, new proposed regulations could significantly change how educational institutions respond to such allegations. This report also examines how federal courts have interpreted Title IX in cases where students sue schools for damages related to sexual abuse or harassment. The report discusses private rights of actions by students against educational institutions for sexual abuse or harassment, federal enforcement of Title IX, constitutional challenges against public universities, and proposed regulations altering schools' responsibilities under Title IX. The Amendments of 1972 prohibit sex discrimination in educational programs receiving federal funding, but do not explicitly allow for private legal action for Title IX violations or define sexual harassment as discrimination. Title IX also does not specify when schools can be held liable for such behavior. Title IX does not specify when schools can be held liable for sexual harassment or abuse. Federal courts have established the legal framework for victims seeking relief under Title IX through a private right of action, including creating liability standards for sexual abuse or harassment by teachers and students. Title IX imposes liability on educational institutions for their response to sexual abuse or harassment, not just the occurrence of the misconduct. The standard for liability is high, requiring a showing of "deliberate indifference" to the conduct. The private right of action under Title IX implies a legal remedy for victims of sex discrimination, while administrative enforcement focuses on institutional policies. Supreme Court decisions outline the requirements for holding educational funding recipients liable for damages related to sexual abuse or harassment. Court decisions, including Gebser v. Lago Vista Independent School District and Davis v. Monroe County Board of Education, establish that an educational institution can be held liable under Title IX for damages related to sexual abuse or harassment only if it shows "deliberate indifference" in responding to such conduct. This means the institution is not automatically liable for a teacher's or principal's actions, and liability is based on the institution's response to the knowledge of the abuse. The Court's standard in Gebser establishes that liability under Title IX is based on a funding recipient's own failure to act adequately in response to known misconduct, not the misconduct itself. Liability only occurs if deliberate indifference is shown, regardless of the egregiousness of the conduct. The Court relied on the statute's administrative enforcement provision to infer legislative intent regarding Title IX liability. Agencies can suspend or cut funds to a recipient for violating Title IX only after advising them and determining voluntary compliance is not possible. This procedure aligns with the Court's standard that liability is based on a recipient's failure to respond adequately to known misconduct, showing deliberate indifference. The Court reasoned that liability under Title IX requires "actual notice" to an "appropriate person" and deliberate indifference in response to known violations. This standard aligns with the statute's enforcement provision, which allows for sanctions only after advising the recipient and determining voluntary compliance is not possible. The Court held that a school district cannot be held liable under Title IX for a teacher's sexual harassment of a student without actual notice and deliberate indifference. Deliberate indifference is a high standard that must cause students to undergo harassment or make them vulnerable to it. Funding recipients are only considered deliberately indifferent if their response to harassment is clearly unreasonable in light of the known circumstances. The Court's standard for deliberate indifference under Title IX requires more than just unreasonableness in a funding recipient's response to sexual abuse or harassment. The recipient must be clearly unreasonable in its response to be held liable. Additionally, other threshold showings are necessary to prevail in a Title IX suit for damages. Gebser requires establishing "actual knowledge of discrimination" by an "appropriate person" at the funding recipient before addressing "deliberate indifference." Failure to prove this may result in dismissal of a Title IX claim for damages related to sexual harassment or abuse. The definition of "appropriate person" and what constitutes "actual" notice have led to disagreements among the circuits.
